articles.title: EPHEMERIS
articles.summary: This document, titled "EPHEMERIS," is a page from an astronomical publication dated October 1983. It features a black and white photograph depicting a celestial event, likely a solar eclipse or a similar coronal phenomenon. The title suggests the full publication would contain astronomical data or predicted positions of celestial objects for that month.

articles.title: UPCOMING EVENTS
articles.summary: This document outlines two upcoming general meetings. The October 15th meeting will feature three SJAA members – Ernie Piini, Jack Peterson, and Bob Fingernut – presenting a slide show on their experience observing the recent solar eclipse in Java. The November 12th meeting will host NASA's Jeff Stargle, who will discuss the detection of extra-solar planets and its connection to infrared observing methods and the Infrared Shuttle Telescope.

articles.title: GENERAL NEWS NOTES
articles.summary: The article announces "The Universe Unfolding," a one-day lecture series presented by the Astronomical Society of the Pacific (ASP) on October 30 at Stanford University, covering diverse astronomy topics from new worlds to extraterrestrial intelligence. It also promotes "Exploring the Universe," a weekly astronomy radio talk show on KGO FM104 hosted by Andrew Fraknoi, which includes public event announcements and call-in questions. Additionally, there's a brief mention of a new member, Anne Lucile Cincotta, born to John and Jane Miller Cincotta.

articles.title: AN INDONESIAN "GERHANA MATAHARI TOTAL"
articles.summary: This article recounts an expedition to Indonesia for the total solar eclipse on June 11, 1983. It describes the cultural significance of "Gerhana Matahari Total" in Indonesia, including mythical beliefs and government efforts to prevent panic, alongside the scientific excitement of astronomers observing the long, five-minute event. The author details their personal experience as part of a 62-person expedition at Gadjah Mada University in Yogyakarta, highlighting optimal weather conditions despite high humidity, the dramatic visual phenomena like the diamond ring and corona, and the unique backdrop of an active Mount Merapi.

articles.title: BY JIM EISELDT
articles.summary: The article details an evaluation of J.D. Grant Park as a potential close-in star party site for the SJAA, following a board meeting. Author Jim Eiseldt and Paul Mancuso visited the park, finding it conveniently located (40 minutes from San Jose) and park officials highly cooperative regarding club usage. While experiencing some sky glow from San Jose, observing conditions were generally favorable for deep sky objects, making it a strong candidate for a regular club observing location.

articles.title: BILL UNRUH'S SITE
articles.summary: The article describes Don Machholz's visit to Bill Unruh's property in the Little Uvis Valley, which serves as a convenient dark-sky observing site, approximately 25 minutes from San Jose. Machholz praises the site's dark skies and low light pollution, despite some light from San Jose in the NNW and a hill blocking the southern horizon. Bill Unruh, a Lick Observatory Historian, plans to build an observatory for his refractor on the property and welcomes club members to observe, requesting a call beforehand for access.

articles.title: THE YEAR THE PERSEIDS FELL FLAT ON ITS FACE
articles.summary: The article expresses frustration over the disappointing Perseid meteor shower in 1983, which delivered far fewer meteors than the expected 100 per hour, despite clear skies and no moon. Observers in the Santa Cruz mountains were particularly let down by the low counts. The author also notes a poor outlook for the 1984 Perseids due to a full moon on August 11th.

articles.title: Oct. 1
articles.summary: This document outlines several astronomical and club-related events for October. It includes star parties at Fremont Peak and Henry Coe State Parks, an SJAA General Meeting at the University of Santa Clara featuring a "Eclipse to Java" presentation, and two indoor star parties at the Los Gatos Red Cross Building, one of which also includes a board meeting.

articles.title: Nov. 5
articles.summary: The document details a series of November events for the San Jose Astronomical Association, including a star party at the new J.D. Grant Ranch site, a general meeting featuring a NASA lecture on exoplanet detection, and a grazing occultation expedition. Additional activities include an indoor star party combined with a board meeting, with no events scheduled for Thanksgiving weekend.

articles.title: Dec. 1
articles.summary: The article announces an upcoming star party on December 1st, with the location still to be determined. It also provides an informative explanation of grazing occultations, describing them as events where the Moon's limb briefly obscures a star, which are observed by the SJAA club to gather valuable scientific data on the Moon's precise location and surface characteristics.

articles.title: BY BOB FINGERHUT
articles.summary: This article reports on several space-related news items, including the NOAA-8 satellite's first rescue assist, the successful STS-8 Space Shuttle mission, and updates on other shuttle flights and satellite deployments like Insat-1B and Oscar 10. It also covers Soviet space station activities, a new shuttle processing contract, Canadian astronaut applications, and the controversial proposal to sell US Earth Remote Sensing Satellites to the private sector.

articles.title: SATCOM 11R Launched Successfully
articles.summary: The RCA SATCOM 11R was successfully launched on Sept. 8 from Cape Canaveral using a Delta launch vehicle. This satellite is intended to replace the SATCOM 11 (launched in 1976) and will be placed in a geosynchronous orbit at 66 degrees west longitude.

articles.title: The "Disappearance" of Two "Bright" Comets
articles.summary: Don Machholz discusses the public's disappointment with two supposedly "bright" comets, IRAS-Araki-Alcock and Sugano-Saigusa-Fujikawa, which seemed to disappear despite close approaches to Earth. He attributes this to public misconceptions about comet appearance (e.g., expecting a tail), the need for dark skies, and the "Delta Effect," where a close comet's light is spread over a larger, fainter area. The article highlights lessons for astronomers on improving communication and managing public expectations regarding comet visibility.

articles.title: BY DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: This article by Don Machholz reports on recent comet activity, noting the recovery of two periodic comets: Wolf (1980n) and Crommelin (1983n). While Comet Wolf is not expected to brighten significantly, Comet Crommelin, recovered brighter than predicted, is anticipated to be visible in binoculars in early 1984. The author also mentions currently visible comets Kopff and Cernis, and promises a review of past discoveries.

articles.title: PAST DISCOVERIES
articles.summary: The article details the discoveries of three comets in October 1978: Comet Seargent (1978m), Periodic Comet Denning-Fujikawa (1978n), and Comet Bradfield (1978o). It describes the circumstances of each discovery, including dates, locations, equipment used, and the comets' characteristics. The analysis also explores why these comets were not observed earlier, often due to their proximity to the sun or faintness prior to their discovery windows.

articles.title: Periodic Comet Kopff (1982k)
articles.summary: The article provides an ephemeris for Periodic Comet Kopff (1982k) from late September to early November, listing its Right Ascension, Declination, and estimated magnitude. It notes that the comet is fading as it moves away from Earth and the Sun, appearing against the Milky Way, and might be slightly brighter than estimated values derived from IUA Circular 3779.

articles.title: Comet Cernis (1983L)
articles.summary: The article presents an ephemeris for Comet Cernis (1983L) from late September to early November 1983, detailing its celestial coordinates, estimated magnitude, distance from Earth, and apparent size. Separately, it includes an administrative notice outlining instructions for membership renewal, specifying where to send forms and remittances to the SJAA treasurer.

articles.title: SJAA MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION/RENEWAL
articles.summary: This document is an application and renewal form for membership in the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA), detailing various membership tiers including options with or without the 'S&T' publication and a junior membership. It also provides comprehensive contact information for the association's officers and board of directors, along with details about its monthly publication, EPHEMERIS.

articles.title: TIME VALUE - DATED
articles.summary: This document is a dated piece of mail from SMA Ephemeris, located in San Jose, CA, postmarked June 1, 1993. The "TIME VALUE - DATED" marking indicates that its contents are time-sensitive and requires prompt attention.
